title: Transaction Relay Service
description:
Create a high-performance service for submitting transactions to blockchains.

## Tasks
1. Create cmd/tx-relay/ service
2. Implement Solana transaction submission:
   - Multiple RPC endpoints with failover
   - Jito bundle submission for MEV protection
   - Priority fee estimation based on recent blocks
3. Implement EVM transaction submission:
   - eth_sendRawTransaction to multiple providers
   - Flashbots Protect for MEV protection (optional)
   - Gas price estimation with EIP-1559 support
4. Build internal gRPC API for transaction submission
5. Implement retry logic with exponential backoff
6. Add transaction status tracking (pending, confirmed, failed)

## RPC Provider Strategy
- Primary: Dedicated/staked RPC nodes (lowest latency)
- Secondary: Helius/QuickNode (reliability)
- Tertiary: Public RPCs (last resort)

\`\`\`
Key: tx:{chain}:{signature}
Value: {
  "status": "pending|confirmed|failed",
  "submitted_at": "...",
  "confirmed_at": "...",
  "slot": 12345,
  "error": null
}
TTL: 1 hour
\`\`\`

## Acceptance Criteria
- Transaction reaches RPC within 20ms of submission
- Automatic retry on transient failures
- Status queryable via API

title: Event Enrichment Pipeline
description:
Implement a Stream Processor that enriches raw blockchain events with
contextual data before they reach user functions.

## Goal
Attach useful metadata to events so WASM functions don't need to make
external API calls for common data like token prices and account labels.

## Current State
- CanonicalEvent payload contains raw blockchain data
- WASM functions must decode and interpret everything themselves
- No price data, token metadata, or account labels attached

## Target State
- Events arrive with USD prices for tokens involved
- Token metadata (decimals, symbol, name) attached
- Known account labels (bridges, DEXes, whales) included
- Cross-chain correlation IDs for bridge transfers

## Enrichment Sources
- Price feeds: Pyth, Chainlink, or aggregated from DEX swaps
- Token metadata: On-chain token registry + cached metadata
- Account labels: Community-maintained address book
- Cross-chain: Internal correlation from bridge events

## Success Metrics
- 95% of token transfers include USD value
- Event payload includes structured metadata object
- No additional API calls needed for common use cases

title: WASM Host Zero-Copy Input
description:
Implement direct memory mapping from Kafka buffer to WASM linear memory,
eliminating intermediate copies.

## Tasks
1. Use franz-go's zero-copy record access (record.Value is already []byte)
2. Implement custom WASM memory allocator that can accept external buffers
3. Map protobuf bytes directly into WASM linear memory
4. Update get_input host function to return pointer to mapped region
5. Implement proper lifetime management (pin buffer until WASM completes)

## Technical Approach
- Use wasmtime's memory import feature to share host memory
- Alternatively, use wasm_memory_data() to write directly to WASM memory
- Avoid Go's json.Marshal entirely - pass raw protobuf bytes

## Dependencies
- mirador-32i (trigger router protobuf)

## Acceptance Criteria
- No intermediate []byte allocations between Kafka and WASM
- Benchmark shows >50% reduction in per-event latency
- Memory profile shows reduced GC pressure

title: Zero-Copy Data Path
description:
Implement true zero-copy data path from Kafka to WASM execution.

## Goal
Eliminate JSON serialization overhead and achieve memory-mapped data access
from Kafka consumer directly into WASM linear memory.

## Current State
- Kafka records are JSON deserialized into Go structs
- Go structs are JSON serialized again for WASM input
- Multiple memory copies and allocations per event

## Target State
- Protobuf encoding end-to-end (Adapter → Kafka → WASM Host)
- Direct memory mapping of Kafka buffer into WASM linear memory
- Sub-millisecond internal latency

## Success Metrics
- p99 internal latency < 5ms (currently ~20ms)
- Zero JSON parsing in hot path
- Memory allocations per event reduced by 80%

title: Transaction Submitter
description:
Enable WASM functions to submit transactions back to blockchains,
completing the reactive loop for trading bots and automation.

## Goal
Allow WASM functions to not just observe events but take action by
submitting signed transactions through the platform's infrastructure.

## Current State
- WASM functions are read-only (log, output, get_input)
- No way to submit transactions from within a function
- Users must build separate infrastructure for execution

## Target State
- New host function: submit_transaction(chain, signed_tx)
- Transaction relay service with low-latency RPC connections
- Priority fee estimation and auto-retry logic
- Transaction status tracking and confirmation

## Security Considerations
- Functions submit PRE-SIGNED transactions (private keys never in platform)
- Rate limiting per tenant
- Transaction size limits
- Optional: Platform-managed signing for approved use cases

## Use Cases
- MEV bots: React to events and submit trades in same millisecond
- Liquidation bots: Monitor health factors and liquidate
- Arbitrage: Detect price discrepancies and execute
- Automation: Trigger actions based on on-chain conditions

## Success Metrics
- Transaction submission latency < 50ms to RPC
- 99.9% submission success rate
- Support for priority fees and Jito bundles (Solana)
